subject: Communication
title: Aristotle's Three Proofs: Ethos, Pathos, Logos
description: A fast breakdown of Aristotle's Three Proofs: Ethos, Pathos, Logos for builders.

hook.text: Aristotle said all persuasion flows from three sources: your character, your audience's emotions, and your logical.

buildup.text: Ethos: trust in the speaker. Pathos: emotional appeal. Logos: logical reasoning.

discovery.text: A doctor recommending exercise (ethos), a charity showing a suffering child (pathos), a scientist presenting data.

twist.text: Most people think logos is most important. Research shows ethos matters most ‚Äî people accept arguments from people.

climax.text: Master communicators weave all three: establish credibility, connect emotionally, and support with evidence.

punchline.text: Aristotle wrote the playbook for persuasion 2,400 years ago. It still works.

quiz.question: Which of Aristotle's three proofs relates to the speaker's credibility?
